Hi Ken,

Thanks for the feedback. Hope you are doing well too.

RTS games a=
re very particular with respect to real-time learning via
neuro-evolution; =
not only you interact with opponents quite rarely
(both few opponents and f=
ew meetings) but also real-time replacement
makes fitness evaluation rather=
 tricky. Replacement does not just
introduce a position for the offspring b=
ut a whole game state
(buildings, warriors, resources) which might correspo=
nd to a local
optima. So, yes, I agree that game design per se has a seriou=
s impact
on the performance of real-time neuro-evolution.

Georgios
 
--- I=
n neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Geor=
gios, I hope things are well.  Thanks for sharing your paper. 
> The proble=
m that rtNEAT requires a high level of interaction indeed
> constrains the =
types of scenarios in which it can be effective.  If
> the NPCs don't get e=
nough interaction, the evaluation is impoverished.
>  Thus there is clearly=
 a challenge when a single player is the only
> focal point of interaction.=
  However, if that single player is is in
> control of a set of agents, eac=
h one of which is a point of
> interaction, I think there is hope that the =
net interaction can be
> sufficient.  However, the balance is delicate and =
the specifics of the
> game obviously become important.  Your paper makes a=
 good point by
> highlighting this issue and showing that it needs to be co=
nsidered in
> the game design if real-time evolution is to be successful.
>=
 
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "g.yannakakis" <yannakakis@> wrot=
e:
> >
> > Hi all,
> > 
> > I thought the following might be of interest to=
 some of you. 
> > 
> > We recently presented a paper at the IEEE Computati=
onal Intelligence
> > and Games 2008 symposium where NEAT and rtNEAT are us=
ed to dynamically
> > adjust the challenge level of a real-time strategy ga=
me.
> > 
> > Here is the article:
> > http://www.itu.dk/~yannakakis/cig08_1=
.pdf
> > 
> > In a few words, NEAT worked just fine in generating diverse N=
PC
> > behaviors like 'win-fast' and 'produce-maximum-numbers-of-warriors'.=

> > rtNEAT, on the other hand did not perform that well and that fast due
=
> > to insufficient interaction in the RTS game under investigation. 
> > 
=
> > Comments and feedback are more than welcome.
> > 
> > Regards
> > Georg=
ios
> >
>
